document.title: Archdiocese of Milwaukee Curriculum Guide, Grade 7

2FFF391BE77A4C718AA599ACEF7E9E00.description:
Solve real-world mathematical problems by adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing rational numbers,
including complex fractions

415BF2F1527342E9B3F14A9697A5C49F.description: Add, subtract, multiply and divide rational numbers

7248BD11D3EC4941B68747C372231991.description: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving the four operations with rational numbers.

461A395F1830433BB100AC14790C9086.description: Apply properties of operations as strategies to multiply and divide rational numbers

53A31D0D26264D4E8D06FA0CCC26FDD8.description: Interpret the quotient of rational numbers by describing real-world contexts

B778167D120B45EFAE442010C18ED8C2.description: Interpret the products of rational numbers by describing real-world contexts

2CF27541B4FB426D86FA33C358546223.description: Apply the properties of operations, particularly distributive property, to multiply rational numbers

B2764D86AF1249D0A235C8CACD31C682.description: Explain that the decimal form of a rational number terminates (stops) in zeroes or repeats

C9A33061C24642CD99D2DA06C4CEC8BB.description: Convert a rational number to a decimal using long division

79BE865C25C74EF0B1DD00A74765D84B.description: Identify how properties of operations can be used to multiply and divide rational numbers

6376A027D53E463689075B2D5C99D1DE.description: Know and describe the rules when dividing signed numbers, integers

406ECA1A324C4084B830CAAA7D398CB0.description: Describe why the quotient is always a rational number

AB952DCFECEE4DFAA50F71685119585F.description: Explain why integers can be divided except when the divisor is 0

30BDAA244FEF4B0F8EDD0C80B3B41B32.description: Know and describe the rules when multiplying signed numbers

E74C55950F434C83ADF9E5D8FCEAF769.description: Recognize that the process for multiplying fractions can be used to multiply rational numbers including integers

78C3EC9782D043D28A74B16A7BE7FD33.description: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division and of fractions to multiply and divide rational numbers.

A4D7C62DC58441688BF35656BB7D93B7.description:
Demonstrate and explain how adding two numbers, p + q, if q is negative, the sum of p and q will be │q│spaces to
the left of p on the number line

F3CC5BFA19D44AFAB7C540182B590B31.description:
Demonstrate and explain how adding two numbers, p + q, if q is positive, the sum of p and q will be │q│spaces to
the right of p on the number line

981CFEF7EFB1472C976503215BB77D6D.description: Apply properties of operations as strategies to add and subtract rational numbers

65AEB42E3C3B45DD9924B0E49CB5A154.description: Apply the principal of subtracting rational numbers in real-world contexts

DB4E189D25804DA181371779B08E1404.description:
Represent the distance between two rational numbers on a number line as the absolute value of their difference
and apply this principle in real-world contexts

4E4F1C328E7745159A90FB56A1755C64.description:
Explain and justify why the sum of p + q is located a distance of │q│in the positive or negative direction from p on
a number line

CB3CAF22BFBD492DBBD69AEAD384EEE1.description: Interpret sums of rational numbers by describing real-world contexts

0DF0588C0299429F9FE3022F34A5B52E.description:
Apply and extend previous understanding to represent addition and subtraction problems of rational numbers
with a horizontal or vertical number line

709EB4F3C2CD428F8E93E699B6DADC0A.description: Identify properties of addition and subtraction when adding and subtracting rational numbers

CEB033C030A6416E80B1AB34C30444F2.description:
Identify subtraction of rational numbers as adding the additive inverse property to subtract rational numbers, p-q
= p +(-q)

F541875FB2894397B80416407D724189.description: Represent and explain how a number and its opposite have a sum of 0 and are additive inverses

CC55D886FC214D258BC9FA9FFF9B9044.description: Describe situations in which opposite quantities combine to make 0

66DA2B86C3BA485A9EFA51102A0BBE37.description: Apply and extend previous understandings of addition and subtraction to add and subtract rational numbers; represent addition and subtraction on a horizontal or vertical number line diagram.

7579B43DB6654D6C976F4BA28ED2A8AF.description: Design and use a simulation to generate frequencies for compound events

20D34525EB9F4E2D9E03FBA4318AE2E5.description:
Choose the appropriate method such as organized lists, tables and tree diagrams to represent sample spaces for
compound events

63C81DE011D142799B5E048FCCA3B255.description: Find probabilities of compound events using organized lists, tables, tree diagrams, etc. and analyze the outcomes

FC3D75B0E91D4C7B852BD91F73C00785.description: Identify the outcomes in the sample space for an everyday event

B51BBFABBB534BC59D4F939BCDC4696F.description:
Know that the probability of a compound event is the fraction of outcomes in the sample space for which the
compound event occurs

60FF6D35A59845339127E121A7B50FFE.description: Define and describe a compound event

A504B33CF3D54755BFBAC05F95F9F572.description: Find probabilities of compound events using organized lists, tables, tree diagrams, and simulation.

2BA3BA75BAAB436DBE0169BD53177D99.description:
Develop a probability model (which may not be uniform) by observing frequencies in data generated from a
chance process

33B2F05BD58F43E7A6BE8C4978985B09.description: Develop a uniform probability model and use it to determine the probability of each outcome/event

E5D61D5AD38547C09F1587CE3858CA30.description: Use models to determine the probability of events

8C9AFA41A6314E03A057FDB57688F537.description: Analyze a probability model and justify why it is uniform or explain the discrepancy if it is not

F64F476837FA4504AD40CA29DD1A2C33.description: Develop a probability model and use it to find probabilities of events. Compare probabilities from a model to observed frequencies; if the agreement is not good, explain possible sources of the discrepancy.

51B7B364C2AB444E944FE634418CAEFE.description: Predict the relative frequency (experimental probability) of an event based on its theoretical probability

4881C8F27FBE4B849E0E7DEC7BEC3B56.description: Determine the relationship between experimental and theoretical probabilities by using the law of large numbers

063E92DAF7E147B290102B67668B730D.description:
Determine relative frequency (experimental probability) is the number of times an outcome occurs divided by the
total number of times the experiment is completed

658C6F09C905447DA7DCEB7892B54AB1.description: Approximate the probability of a chance event by collecting data on the chance process that produces it and observing its long-run relative frequency, and predict the approximate relative frequency given the probability. For example, when rolling a number cube 600 times, predict that a 3 or 6 would be rolled roughly 200 times, but probably not exactly 200 times.

9328D77A98F74B958E120AB16CB15962.description:
Draw conclusions to determine that a greater likelihood occurs as the number of favorable outcomes approaches
the total number of outcomes

60822EEEF16E4FDDB79B3D6BA89B14F6.description: Know that as probability moves closer to 0 it is decreasingly likely to happen

3741698AC5AD485CBE77BA164FEDAC09.description: Know that as probability moves closer to 1 it is increasingly likely to happen

4EB0174CC9DF48988334EFECE458AE83.description: Know that a random event with a probability of ½ is equally likely to happen

438D2C6BCA4F4E61A7507D8C52C2C562.description: Know that probability is expressed as a number between 0 and 1

5830690AE5EC4FE3A9799D9D16BBFC9D.description: Understand that the probability of a chance event is a number between 0 and 1 that expresses the likelihood of the event occurring. Larger numbers indicate greater likelihood. A probability near 0 indicates an unlikely event, a probability around 1/2 indicates an event that is neither unlikely nor likely, and a probability near 1 indicates a likely event.

661E1A87FA16476097C77B6586F57000.description: Draw informal comparative inferences about two populations from random samples

9D68FB5A07E64C63881B2D3D585373A5.description: Analyze and interpret data using measures of central tendency and variability

A135D9B34507455EB9C7085AB2957A1C.description: Find measures of central tendency (mean, median, and mode) and measures of variability (range, quartile, etc.)

D90765121F66412B8C7886F1150D1278.description: Use measures of center and measures of variability for numerical data from random samples to draw informal comparative inferences about two populations. For example, decide whether the words in a chapter of a seventh-grade science book are generally longer than the words in a chapter of a fourth-grade science book.

BD7BCD17304145F491494B9C4AC83501.description:
Compare the differences in the measure of central tendency in two numerical data distributions by measuring the
difference between the centers and expressing it as a multiple of a measure of variability

6B76EE142E46400F9955216FD9D35757.description:
Compare two numerical data distributions on a graph by visually comparing data displays, and assessing the
degree of visual overlap

ADE5FD81607D4F8797F42A0272AE9953.description:
Identify measures of variation including upper quartile, lower quartile, upper extreme-maximum, lower extrememinimum,
range, interquartile range, and mean absolute deviation

D990C6334D904776A85557A4A8459749.description: Identify measures of central tendency (mean, median, and mode) in a data distribution

91A04A7DAAF8441AB2908EF72FF36EC1.description: Informally assess the degree of visual overlap of two numerical data distributions with similar variabilities, measuring the difference between the centers by expressing it as a multiple of a measure of variability. For example, the mean height of players on the basketball team is 10 cm greater than the mean height of players on the soccer team, about twice the variability (mean absolute deviation) on either team; on a dot plot, the separation between the two distributions of heights is noticeable.

B7596966E7EA48AF9A92C93A2FFB7F24.description:
Generate multiple samples (or simulated samples) of the same size to determine the variation in estimates or
predictions by comparing and contrasting the samples

69EB31810A0743B7994C16E6F491D07A.description:
Analyze and interpret data from a random sample to draw inferences about a population with an unknown
characteristic of interest

DC2E2250C1CC463AA94C896E1B6C29AD.description: Use data from a random sample to draw inferences about a population with an unknown characteristic of interest. Generate multiple samples (or simulated samples) of the same size to gauge the variation in estimates or predictions. For example, estimate the mean word length in a book by randomly sampling words from the book; predict the winner of a school election based on randomly sampled survey data. Gauge how far off the estimate or prediction might be.

4968D79FE08E4EF2A067FAF57E4F0275.description: Generalize that random sampling tends to produce representative samples and support valid inferences

B276EF812E0C4B99B523B821BFB0665B.description: Apply statistics to gain information about a population from a sample of the population

35668547F09A445489BE6C96C1354D03.description:
Know that generalizations about a population from a sample are valid only if the sample is representative of that
population

25C997EA5421457D93E15DB670EFA22C.description: Recognize sampling techniques such as convenience, random, systematic, and voluntary

24ED1FFBF9194CDF8226D1157C9BA9E8.description:
Know statistics terms such as population, sample, sample size, random sampling, generalizations, valid, biased
and unbiased

A85DE3321ED64F65B423CD001FD24199.description: Understand that statistics can be used to gain information about a population by examining a sample of the population; generalizations about a population from a sample are valid only if the sample is representative of that population. Understand that random sampling tends to produce representative samples and support valid inferences.

6C4E50485B9A48F59BAC4EFA50F55504.description: Apply proportional reasoning to solve multi-step ratio and percent problems

BD50580A8625423E96F58B4225C76E1C.description: Recognize situations in which proportional relationships apply

0C2D061E3DFD45CD8132FC04ED18CF16.description: Use proportional relationships to solve multistep ratio and percent problems. Examples: simple interest, tax, markups and markdowns, gratuities and commissions, fees, percent increase and decrease, percent error.

33AADFAB31DD4956858103163936DD7C.description: Explain what the points on a graph of a proportional relationship mean in terms of a specific situation

6B5508D1055E4B038FB1208DE212D14B.description: Represent proportional relationships by writing equations

BDD3C194399E4C99B82B7790EFFF72A3.description:
Analyze tables, graphs, equations, diagrams, and verbal descriptions of proportional relationships to identify the
constant of proportionality

CAF6AF54BF8C49078500F7409CA16B68.description:
Analyze two ratios to determine if they are proportional to one another with a variety of strategies (e.g., using
tables, graphs, pictures, etc.)

D7C069F586454D4BBC7EE4DA2CDBE799.description: Recognize what (1, r) on a graph represents, where r is the unit rate

5557B3359CCD4B1E899C97C900DDABFE.description: Recognize what (0, 0) represents on the graph of a proportional relationship

D6E50F6E69364E26BB63601C17243D4D.description: Define a constant of proportionality as a unit rate

63BAA1D98F10421F82D225F4C1743F69.description: Know that a proportion is a statement of equality between two ratios

78B5E726B69F4F92A33A69E21E9433F5.description: Recognize and represent proportional relationships between quantities.

951D0E436F964929A71BAB4A6A186EA3.description: Compute unit rates associated with ratios of fractions in like or different units

B0F972E1716B4297AEF77EFC38309BC0.description: Compute unit rates associated with ratios of fractions, including ratios of lengths, areas and other quantities measured in like or different units. For example, if a person walks 1/2 mile in each 1/4 hour, compute the unit rate as the complex fraction 1/2/1/4 miles per hour, equivalently 2 miles per hour.

6B057A5B6DAC4C178D187ADB9DB850C9.description:
Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving area, surface area and volume of two-and threedimensional
objects composed of triangles, quadrilaterals, polygons, cubes, and right prisms

6EC954F54E244E4E8AC9084B7B961F32.description:
Know the formulas for area and volume and the procedure for finding surface area and when to use them in realworld
and mathematical problems

BEE98764069B4D6E99AA98F8E4E7E474.description: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving area, volume and surface area of two- and three-dimensional objects composed of triangles, quadrilaterals, polygons, cubes, and right prisms.

86F3889933C948589D4EE8CF040D2E20.description:
Determine unknown angle measures by writing and solving algebraic equations based on relationships between
angles

4140590329BA4882B1D69B0F7BCA7BC0.description: Determine complements and supplements of a given angle

4A54DE9EA9594C67B33828923F1FF8AA.description: Identify and recognize types of angles: supplementary, complementary, vertical, adjacent

0149AFEC3F434B95A9E34B1E77FFA722.description: Use facts about supplementary, complementary, vertical, and adjacent angles in a multi-step problem to write and solve simple equations for an unknown angle in a figure.

23AE791C1FBC4F68AF7F53E6F7173D24.description: Given the area of a circle, find its circumference

D4499492DE284060947C325651A909C5.description: Informally derive the relationship between circumference and area of a circle

3F683EC3E6F743E482B49A9B6D967FF1.description: Informally derive the relationship between circumference and area of a circle

EBA28C7EF37945CC98938D72AF3243B9.description: Justify the formulas for area and circumference of a circle and how they relate to pi (n)

29B3366BB02B449D9BFE57B9E91E66AD.description: Apply circumference or area formulas to solve mathematical and real-world problems

7E9D5BFEA0D74235AFF32ED000FD35E8.description: Justify that pi (n) can be derived from the circumference and diameter of a circle

AEDFE4F6C55E492D8EE68EF6DF2D6431.description: Know the formulas for area and circumference of a circle

0F704E8B986A4F2C8AC3D86DFFF96C2F.description: Know the parts of a circle including radius, diameter, area, circumference, center, and chord

FD56EE6D8A314E4AA3787DE7D25CDDF9.description: Know the formulas for the area and circumference of a circle and use them to solve problems; give an informal derivation of the relationship between the circumference and area of a circle.

514E4DE91E0A497EA378870C3886C917.description: Analyze three-dimensional shapes by examining two-dimensional cross-sections

673E87FDEEB1420995A9D51B1667E6FA.description:
Describe the two-dimensional figures that result from slicing a three-dimensional figure such as a right
rectangular prism or pyramid

6A52899302304B6586DAF0DD6E3635F4.description: Define “slicing” as the cross-section of a 3-D figure

F66DD14B70AE478293F62C6CE4BF08E7.description: Describe the two-dimensional figures that result from slicing three-dimensional figures, as in plane sections of right rectangular prisms and right rectangular pyramids.

140B9C40C20E4363B620E7A70C13205D.description:
Construct triangles from three given side measures to determine when there is a unique triangle, more than one
triangle, or no triangle

E7333EA89DC24F85AF7159649D6E148E.description:
Construct triangles from three given angle measures to determine when there is a unique triangle, more than one
triangle, or no triangle

4F97BADF4DD243EBB61689E09B527697.description:
Analyze given conditions, based on the three measures of angles or sides of a triangle, to determine when there is
a unique triangle, more than one triangle, or no triangle

E0741379CB754EED9C7A6FD9B0B5971C.description: Know which conditions create unique triangles, more than one triangle, or no triangle

C5E5A99F5F0244EDB048F5C259FDA7A4.description: Draw (freehand, with ruler and protractor, and with technology) geometric shapes with given conditions. Focus on constructing triangles from three measures of angles or sides, noticing when the conditions determine a unique triangle, more than one triangle, or no triangle.

914F6885C621485DAB5E64826EE637A1.description: Reproduce a scale drawing that is proportional to a given geometric figure using a different scale

08106DEF784F464A958F6A63273467DA.description: Compute lengths and areas from scale drawings using strategies such as proportions

BDB5780D3758450F99E8648E0C101BC4.description: Solve problems involving scale drawings of geometric figures using scale factors

B1FEA45B61C14E908B3AA59CB3E6D002.description: Use ratios and proportions to create scale drawing

05F7CE7B0D524C389557DADED2D5A89D.description: Identify corresponding sides of scaled geometric figures

C6CBB84400EC4FA19847743AA7AAABBB.description: Solve problems involving scale drawings of geometric figures, including computing actual lengths and areas from a scale drawing and reproducing a scale drawing at a different scale.

0C8BD09C98D244D88D29C84316810238.description: Fluently solve equations of the form px + q = r and p( x + q) = r with speed and accuracy

0DC35C63D3CE4ECA83A746EAF6C4FED0.description: Solve word problems leading to equations of the form px + q = r and p (x + q) = r

9E148B65C0D241EBBFD13EE84B998B16.description:
Graph the solution set of the inequality of the form px + q > r or px + q < r, where p, q, and r are specific rational
numbers

06EABCD2B62B4850B0B70857F24B6F4D.description:
Use variables and construct equations to represent quantities of the form px + q = r and p(x + q) = r from realworld
and mathematical problems

E33B5D0DD1DB4D3BA6B175CD826817EE.description: Identify the sequence of operations used to solve an algebraic equation of the form px + q = r and p(x + q) = r

2D89453E57004DD58FF9C3A9C7F0C2CC.description:
Solve word problems leading to inequalities of the form px + q > r or px + q < r, where p, q, and r are specific
rational numbers

E66AD4EF31AC4D01AC83391F95AFAE50.description: Interpret the solution set of an inequality in the context of the problem

BF820160D42F4838BFAC364EFF926E04.description:
Compare an algebraic solution to an arithmetic solution by identifying the sequence of the operations used in
each approach

17D03E13A7CE4C3593F257EF858EFE52.description: Use variables to represent quantities in a real-world or mathematical problem, and construct simple equations and inequalities to solve problems by reasoning about the quantities.

27250670AF89409BAC7AB388770696F1.description:
Solve multi-step real-life and mathematical problems posed with positive and negative rational numbers in any
form

F636CDA5D9D144FFA9DBA51C4808AA00.description: Convert between numerical forms as appropriate

C79C012FC0C048B79B8D0EB962EB40F2.description: Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies

0FFF83193BF34243AF9396DD151CA5DC.description: Apply properties of operations to calculate with numbers in any form

33B761FCA19B4D68A9899FE991F7BF5B.description: Solve multi-step real-life and mathematical problems posed with positive and negative rational numbers in any form (whole numbers, fractions, and decimals), using tools strategically. Apply properties of operations to calculate with numbers in any form; convert between forms as appropriate; and assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies. For example: If a woman making $25 an hour gets a 10% raise, she will make an additional 1/10 of her salary an hour, or $2.50, for a new salary of $27.50. If you want to place a towel bar 9 3/4 inches long in the center of a door that is 27 1/2 inches wide, you will need to place the bar about 9 inches from each edge; this estimate can be used as a check on the exact computation.

102BCEAA2D244F989323AD48E407DA10.description:
Rewrite an expression in an equivalent form in order to provide insight about how quantities are related in a
problem context

090F7391BC23417784AFA09BCB79C53A.description: Write equivalent expressions with fractions, decimals, percents, and integers

0BC146FCA2D049CE87017C4912A71A11.description: Understand that rewriting an expression in different forms in a problem context can shed light on the problem and how the quantities in it are related. For example, a + 0.05a = 1.05a means that "increase by 5%" is the same as "multiply by 1.05."

061C2CF565284E928CD5D950EBE9FB93.description: Factor and expand linear expressions with rational coefficients using the distributive property

B0A1F7A79A0D462099224F3BA0CB5FD5.description: Combine like terms with rational coefficients

CB5C4A8015D343B29C1F3E9257E1060A.description:
Apply properties of operations as strategies to add, subtract, factor, and expand linear expressions with rational
coefficients

977DDC7868284969B497C650D8245EBC.description: Apply properties of operations as strategies to add, subtract, factor, and expand linear expressions with rational coefficients.
